Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: The Involvement of Blue Light in Plant Immunity
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plants are dependent on light for their survival and can perceive different colors of light with various sensors. Phototropins are blue light sensors that trigger a variety of plant responses that poise the plant for efficient photosynthesis. At daybreak plants are particularly susceptible to microbial pathogens so it would be logical for plants to evolve the use of light sensors to cue the immune system of the potential threat of a new day. The investigators have compelling data that suggest phototropins are components of the plant immune system. These data concern a protein from a plant pathogenic bacterium which the pathogen injects into plant cells to facilitate infection. The data suggest that the injected protein blocks phototropin function and thereby inhibits immune responses and promotes infection. This project will determine the extent to which phototropins contribute to plant immunity. The investigators will determine the molecular consequence of the interaction of phototropins with the injected bacterial protein and will determine whether blue light, through its influence on phototropins, has an effect on plant immunity. The investigators will determine where phototropins localize in the plant cell after plants are treated with pathogens or inducers of plant immunity. The experiments of this project will offer broad and comprehensive training for students and postdoctoral associates. The PI is involved in educational programs that will provide high school students and undergraduates research and training experiences in plant pathology and plant immunity at the University of Nebraska. The findings of this project may lead to the development of crops with improved tolerance to biotic stress.

Phototropins are blue light receptor kinases that trigger a variety of plant responses that poise the plant for efficient photosynthesis which is critical for the success of the plant. In Arabidopsis there are two phototropins, phototropin 1 (Phot1) and phototropin 2 (Phot2). These receptors control several responses that ensure that plants are poised to carry-out photosynthesis. The investigators have compelling preliminary data that suggest that phototropins also act as components of plant immunity. They will determine the extent that phototropins affect the plant immune system. The specific objectives of the project are: (1) Determine the molecular consequence of the interaction of phot1/2 with the Pseudomonas syringae effector HopK1; (2) Determine the extent that blue light affects plant immunity; (3) Investigate dynamic cellular localization of phototropins after biotic stress.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. This project has significant intellectual merit because it revealed phototropins are involved in plant immunity. We actually went further than phototropins and showed that strong blue light induces plant immunity in a manner dependent on one of the phototropins. Any new component of plant immunity has much intellectual merit because it will increase our understanding of how plants tolerate biotic stress. This research should be of great interest to the photobiology and plant-microbe research communities. 

Broader Impacts. We conducted outreach activities involving high school and undergraduate students to expose them to the process of research and to become familiar with the fields of plant biology and host-microbe interactions. To strengthen K-12 student interest in STEM fields, we offered research-based education to high school students through Young Nebraska Scientist Program at the University of Nebraska. These students gained research experience, lab skills, scientific communication, and the responsibility that comes with working a full-time job.  

Outcomes of the award. This project was focused on Arabidopsis blue light receptors called phototropins. We found that a type III effector called HopK1 interacted with the two phototropins (phot1 and phot2) present in Arabidopsis. Type III effectors are injected into plant and animal pathogens by their type III protein secretion systems. HopK1 is an effector found in the Arabidopsis pathogen Pseudomonas syringae pv tomato DC3000 (Pto DC3000). The majority of type III effectors target components of the plant immune system, which suggests that phot1 and phot2 are newly identified components of plant immunity. To confirm the interaction we directly tested if phot1 and phot2 could interact with HopK1-HA in transgenic Arabidopsis plants expressing HopK1-HA by co-immunoprecipitation and immunoblot analyses. We also carried out bimolecular fluorescence complementation (BiFC) assays where the phototropins and HopK1 were fused with N-terminal or C-terminal YFP moieties and transiently expressed in N. benthamiana using Agrobacterium. Confocal micrograph images indicated that HopK1 strongly interacts with phototropins and these interactions appeared to occur in the cytoplasm and chloroplasts.

In the course of working with transgenic Arabidopsis plants expressing HopK1-HA, we found that plants expressing HopK1-HA phenocopied the Arabidopsis phot1phot2 mutant. We found that HopK1-HA expressing plants had closed stomata, were not phototropic, and were impaired in the ability of their chloroplast to both avoid strong light and to accumulate in weaker light, all of which are phenotypes of the Arabidopsis phot1phot2 mutant. Arabidopsis plants expressing HopK1-HA phenocopied the Arabidopsis phot1phot2 mutant.

To assess whether phototropins are involved in plant immunity against P. syringae we spray-inoculated wild-type Pto DC3000 on the widely used A. thaliana Col-3 gl1 (homozygous recessive glabrous1) phot1-5, phot2-1, phot1-5phot2-1 mutants and the corresponding wild type Col-3 plants (21). Arabidopsis phot2-1 and the double mutant exhibited enhanced susceptibility based on increased disease symptoms as well as increased growth of Pto DC3000 in leaf tissue. However, the Pto DC3000 in planta growth and the disease symptoms produced on Col-3 gl1 phot1-5 mutant resembled wild-type suggesting that phot2, but not phot1, is a component of plant immunity.

We also infected the phot mutants with Pto DC3000 hopK1. Importantly, the Pto DC3000 hopK1 mutant no longer exhibited a reduced growth assay and disease symptoms when infected into the Col-3 gl1 phot2 and phot1phot2 mutants. From the bacteria growth we found that the phot2 and double mutant can fully restore hopK1’s virulence to wild type levels. This suggests that phot2 is a primary in planta target of HopK1.

HopK1 is predicted to be a deamidase using the Phyre program. Protein alignments with other deamidases identified that the cysteine residue at position 218 of HopK1 is predicted to be in the active site. We made site-directed mutations in HopK1 substituting the cysteine residue with an alanine (HopK1C218A). The HopK1C218A mutant was used in complementation experiments with the Pto DC3000 hopK1 mutant and the phot2 and phot1phot2 mutants did not exhibit an enhanced susceptibility phenotype consistent with HopK1 being a deamidase.  Additionally, plants expressing the HopK1C218A mutant no longer phenocopied the Arabidopsis phot1phot2 mutant further suggesting that HopK1C218A mutant was not active and that HopK1 may be a deamidase.

To further test blue light effect on plant innate immunity we adopted the LED chamber AR66L(Percival Scientific, Perry, IA) to grow the Arabidopsis under the LED light. Arabidopsis Col-0, phot1, cry1, cry2 and cry1cry2 grow under strong blue light show more resistant to Pto DC3000 compared to the Arabidopsis grow under medium blue light based on the symptoms development. Most important the different effect of blue light intensity on the plant innate immunity is abolished in the phot2 and phot1phot2 mutants background. This means that the blue light mediated immunity is dependent on phot2. The phot2 is the major blue light receptor to adjust the innate immunity.
